comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Related photos in the series may hold clues - [Digital ID: 4481_a026_000010] Panorama from the infield - [Digital IDs: 4481_a026_000012 & 4481_a026_000011] Panorama from the grandstand – [Digital IDs: 4481_a026_000013 & 4481_a026_000014]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Fantastic work! A plethora of panoramas! I think the photo / series is much earlier - possibly mid 1880s. It gets very confusing with which grandstand is "new" in the Trove newspaper reports, and the various extensions, fires and rebuilds. The style of the photos suggest earlier to me, as does the lack of Boater hats. Also in the bottom right photo above, Randwick is still just a collection of large houses, but I think the left photo shows the Tram sheds (1880?) in King Street. There is a great illustration of the new grand stand when it was built in 1876, which almost matches this photo, except for a newer St Leger Stand (1882) - Illustrated Sydney News 29/4/1876 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/63333703

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Vivid contemporary description of "An Off Day at Randwick" - SMH 29/4/1882 p.7 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13510234

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
I forgot I had a Randwick Racecourse photo in my collection. Much later though, 1920s.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/5564454088/](Apologies for the shameless self-promotion!)

comment.author: 46035582@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] The horses look like a shock wave...fabulous

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] A great illustration of the soon-to-be-finished grandstand! So we now know "c. April 1879" is a start date. 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I love your photo - why are they all standing in lines, are they the 'bookies'? Seems so orderly.

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] As I said before, these stands are very confusing.  But I think the photo (and the series) is between 1882 (St Leger Stand as seen here) and the extensions to the Grand Stand in c.1889.  So far!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] There have been several suggestions. They are clustered on small raised platforms, each of which has a pole and a sign at the top. I first thought it may be the owner's area, but having a look at the original resolution again, bookies as you and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] suggested looks more likely - there are men with straps over their shoulders by each of the stands.
